title: Pete Kuharchek
text:
Peter C. Kuharchek (born November 12, 1947) is an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> coach and former player, whose coaching career spanned over 40 years at the high school, collegiate and professional levels. He was the <a href="head%20coach">head coach</a> for the <a href="Rhein%20Fire">Rhein Fire</a> of the <a href="NFL%20Europe">NFL Europe</a> League (NFLEL) from 2001 to 2005, compiling a record of 24 wins and 28 losses. At the collegiate level, he most notably served as defensive coordinator at the <a href="Memphis%20Tigers%20football">University of Memphis</a> from 1987 to 1989, and the <a href="UTEP%20Miners%20football">University of Texas at El Paso</a> (UTEP) from 1994 through 1995. Besides his tenure in the NFLEL — which also included stints as assistant for the <a href="Orlando%20Thunder">Orlando Thunder</a> (1992) and Rhein Fire (1996–2000) — Kuharchek worked in four other professional leagues — including the <a href="United%20States%20Football%20League">United States Football League</a> (USFL), <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">Canadian Football League</a> (CFL), <a href="Arena%20Football%20League">Arena Football League</a> (AFL), and <a href="United%20Football%20League%20%282009%E2%80%932012%29">United Football League</a> (UFL). Most notably, he was the defensive coordinator for the CFL's <a href="Toronto%20Argonauts">Toronto Argonauts</a> in 2009.
As of 2020, he was serving as the defensive coordinator of the <a href="XFL%20%282020%29">XFL</a>'s Team 9 farm team.
Playing career.
A native of <a href="Johnstown%2C%20Pennsylvania">Johnstown, Pennsylvania</a>, Kuharchek attended <a href="Conemaugh%20Township%20Area%20Middle/Senior%20High%20School">Conemaugh Township High School</a> in <a href="Davidsville%2C%20Pennsylvania">Davidsville, Pennsylvania</a>, where he lettered in <a href="High%20school%20football">football</a>, <a href="Track%20and%20field">track</a>, and <a href="wrestling">wrestling</a>. Following graduation, he originally enrolled at <a href="George%20Washington%20University">George Washington University</a>, located in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> Kuharchek played two seasons as a <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a> for the <a href="George%20Washington%20Colonials%20football">Colonials</a> under head coach Jim Camp. In late November 1966, he was part of the team which played the final game in George Washington football history, a 16–7 loss to Villanova. The school's board of trustees voted to end the football program in January 1967 and Kuharchek transferred to the <a href="University%20of%20Tampa">University of Tampa</a> in <a href="Tampa%2C%20Florida">Florida</a>. The Pennsylvania native started two seasons at linebacker for the <a href="Tampa%20Spartans%20football">Spartans</a>, which at the time were coached by <a href="Fran%20Curci">Fran Curci</a>. He led the team in tackles both of these years. In 1969, Kuharchek graduated with a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Science">Bachelor of Science</a> degree in <a href="business%20administration">business administration</a> and subsequently joined the Spartans coaching staff, helping to coach the team's linebackers for one season. He was elected to the University of Tampa Athletic Hall of Fame in 2002.
Coaching career.
Following a two-year hiatus from football, Kuharchek became an assistant coach at <a href="Tampa%20Catholic%20High%20School">Tampa Catholic High School</a> in 1972, spending the next four years as <a href="defensive%20coordinator">defensive coordinator</a> at the institute. In 1976, his former college coach Fran Curci, then the head coach at the <a href="University%20of%20Kentucky">University of Kentucky</a>, invited him to join his coaching staff as a <a href="graduate%20assistant">graduate assistant</a> coach. After only one season with the <a href="Kentucky%20Wildcats%20football">Wildcats</a>, Kuharchek moved on to the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin%E2%80%93Eau%20Claire">University of Wisconsin–Eau Claire</a>, serving as the Blugolds' defensive coordinator for two years. In 1979, he became the secondary coach at the <a href="College%20of%20the%20Holy%20Cross">College of the Holy Cross</a>, located in <a href="Worcester%2C%20Massachusetts">Worcester, Massachusetts</a>. Kuharchek spend two years on the <a href="Holy%20Cross%20Crusaders%20football">Crusaders</a> staff before being hired at <a href="East%20Tennessee%20State%20University">East Tennessee State University</a> in <a href="Johnson%20City%2C%20Tennessee">Johnson City</a> as the <a href="East%20Tennessee%20State%20Buccaneers%20football">Buccaneers</a> defensive coordinator.
In 1983, he entered the professional coaching ranks when he was hired as an assistant coach by the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Bandits">Tampa Bay Bandits</a> of the fledgling <a href="United%20States%20Football%20League">United States Football League</a> (USFL). The franchise was coached by former <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a> winner <a href="Steve%20Spurrier">Steve Spurrier</a> and finished each season of its three-year existence with a winning record. Kuharchek oversaw the team's strength and conditioning program and helped coaching the linebackers. In December 1985, <a href="Charlie%20Bailey">Charlie Bailey</a> was named head coach at Memphis State University — now the <a href="University%20of%20Memphis">University of Memphis</a>. Bailey was one of his coaches at the University of Tampa and both had worked together on the coaching staffs at Kentucky and Tampa Bay. Kuharchek was hired as the <a href="Memphis%20Tigers%20football">Tigers</a> linebackers coach in January 1986 and elevated to the position of defensive coordinator twelve months later.
On January 21, 2009, Kuharchek was named <a href="defensive%20coordinator">defensive coordinator</a> of the <a href="Toronto%20Argonauts">Toronto Argonauts</a> of the <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">Canadian Football League</a>. He returned to the Argonauts in 2015 as the inside linebackers coach, after several seasons with the <a href="Omaha%20Nighthawks">Omaha Nighthawks</a>.
In 2020, Kuharchek was announced as the defensive assistant coach for Team 9, the internal farm team/practice squad of the <a href="XFL%20%282020%29">revived XFL</a>.
